raw_text:
Car giant hit by Mercedes slump
 
 A slump in profitability at luxury car maker Mercedes has prompted a big drop in profits at parent DaimlerChrysler.
 
 The German-US carmaker saw fourth quarter operating profits fall to 785m euros ($1bn) from 2.4bn euros in 2003. Mercedes-Benz's woes - its profits slid to just 20m euros - obscured a strong performance from the Chrysler group whose returns met market expectations. Mercedes faces fierce competition in the luxury car sector from BMW and but hopes to revive its fortunes by 2006.
 
 Mercedes' profits over the period compared unfavourably with 2003's 784m euro figure and were well below analyst expectations of 374m euros. For the year as a whole, its operating profits fell 46% to 1.6bn euros. Sales of Mercedes' brands fell 2% as demand cooled, while revenues were affected by the weakness of the US dollar.
 
 The carmaker blamed the fall in profits on high launch costs for new models and losses from its Mercedes Smart mini-car range. Mercedes is hoping to increase productivity by 3bn euros, having negotiated 500m euros in annual savings with German workers last year. The firm said it was determined to retain Mercedes' position as the world's most successful luxury brand. However, DaimlerChrysler's shares fell 1.5% on the news. "While all these divisions are doing well the big worries continue to surround Mercedes-Benz," Michael Rabb, an analyst with Bank Sal Oppenheim, told Reuters.
 
 In contrast, Chrysler enjoyed a 5% annual increase in unit sales while revenues - calculated in US dollars - rose 10%. The US division - whose marques include Dodge and Jeep - transformed a full year operating loss of 506m euros in 2003 into a 1.4bn euros profit last year.
 
 Overall, DaimlerChrysler saw worldwide vehicle sales rise 8% to 4.7 million in 2004 while total revenues added 4% to 142bn euros. Chrysler's strong performance helped the world's fifth largest carmaker boost net income by 400m euros to 2.5bn euros.
 
 "The year 2004 shows that our strategy works well - even in such a challenging competitive environment," said Jurgen Schrempp, DaimlerChrysler's chairman. DaimlerChrysler took a 475m euro hit in costs stemming from a defects scandal at its joint venture, Japanese subsidiary Fuso. DaimlerChrysler last week agreed a compensation package with partner Mitsubishi Motors which will see it buy out its stake in Fuso. Looking forward, DaimerChrysler's profits are expected to be slightly higher in 2005. However, it is expecting "significant improvements" in profitability in 2006 as a result of a major investment in the Mercedes product range.
llama3.2:1b:
DaimlerChrysler reported a 46% decline in operating profits to 1.6bn euros for the year, compared to 2.4bn euros in 2003. The company's luxury car brand Mercedes-Benz fell to 785m euros in fourth-quarter profits, down from 784m euros in 2003. Sales of Mercedes' brands declined by 2% due to cooling demand, while revenues were affected by the weakness of the US dollar.

Mercedes blamed high launch costs and losses from its Smart mini-car range for the decline in profits. The company is seeking to increase productivity and negotiate annual savings with German workers. DaimlerChrysler shares fell 1.5% on the news.

In contrast, Chrysler's strong performance was driven by a 5% year-over-year increase in unit sales and a 10% rise in revenues in US dollars. The US division saw a full-year operating loss revert to a profit of 506m euros last year after a significant loss in 2003.

DaimlerChrysler also reported a 475m euro hit in costs related to a defects scandal at its Japanese subsidiary Fuso, and agreed to buy out Mitsubishi Motors' stake in the joint venture. The company expects profits to be slightly higher in 2005 but is expecting "significant improvements" in profitability in 2006.
llama3.2:3b: DaimlerChrysler reports big drop in fourth quarter profits due to Mercedes slump, but Chrysler's strong performance offsets losses, with overall net income rising by 400m euros to 2.5bn euros.
gemma2:2b: Mercedes-Benz suffered a significant drop in profits in Q4 and for the year, impacting parent DaimlerChrysler's performance. The decline was attributed to high launch costs and losses from its Smart mini-car range. Despite this, Chrysler achieved strong sales growth and profitability. DaimlerChrysler witnessed a 8% rise in global vehicle sales with higher revenues overall but faces challenges with Mercedes' declining profits.  DaimlerChrysler expects profitability to improve significantly in 2006 thanks to an investment in the Mercedes product range.
qwen2.5:0.5b: DaimlerChrysler reported a fourth quarter loss of 1.6 billion euros for its car division. Mercedes-Benz's performance fell short of analysts' expectations, with the luxury car maker's profits down from 2003 levels. DaimlerChrysler saw annual sales rise to 47 million in 2004, but total revenue added only 4% to 1.5 trillion euros as Chrysler's performance improved. The carmaker expects a slight increase in profitability in the following year while facing a challenge from Mercedes-Benz's continued presence.
qwen2.5:1.5b: DaimlerChrysler suffered a loss in fourth-quarter operating profits due to Mercedes-Benz's decline, with Chrysler posting strong performance and increased revenues despite economic challenges.
qwen2.5:3b: A slump in Mercedes-Benz profits has led to a significant drop in DaimlerChrysler's fourth quarter operating profits. Despite strong performance from Chrysler, Mercedes-Benz's woes obscured this, with profits falling to just 20m euros compared to 784m euros in 2003. Analysts expected 374m euros, but actual profits were only 1.6bn euros for the year, a fall of 46%. High launch costs and losses from Mercedes Smart range contributed to these figures. DaimlerChrysler's shares fell slightly. Chrysler saw unit sales increase by 5%, revenue rise by 10%, turning its full-year loss into a profit last year. Overall, DaimlerChrysler's net income rose 400m euros to 2.5bn euros in 2004. In 2006, the company expects significant improvements in profitability due to major investment in Mercedes product range.
opencoder:1.5b: The text provided presents a detailed analysis of a company's financial performance during a year, highlighting key profits and losses. It does not elaborate on specific problems or concerns that occurred, instead focusing solely on the summary and focusing on the main points summarized. The objective is to summarize the key points in plain language, keeping only the important details.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should capture the main points from the original text:

1. The slump in profitability at luxury car maker Mercedes-Benz has prompted a big drop in profits at parent DaimlerChrysler.
2. Mercedes-Benz's woes - its profits fell to 20m euros - obscured a strong performance from the Chrysler group whose returns met market expectations.
3. Mercedes' profits over the period compared unfavourably with 2003's 784m euro figure and were well below analyst expectations of 374m euros.
4. The carmaker blamed the fall in profits on high launch costs for new models and losses from its Mercedes Smart mini-car range.
5. Mercedes is hoping to increase productivity by 3bn euros, having negotiated 500m euros in annual savings with German workers last year.
6. While all these divisions are doing well the big worries continue to surround Mercedes-Benz's position as the world's most successful luxury brand.
7. DaimlerChrysler's shares fell 1.5% on the news. "While all these divisions are doing well the big worries continue to surround Mercedes-Benz's position as the world's most successful luxury brand."
8. The year 2004 shows that our strategy works well - even in such a challenging competitive environment.
9. DaimlerChrysler took a 475m euro hit in costs stemming from a defects scandal at its joint venture, Japanese subsidiary Fuso.
10. DaimlerChrysler last week agreed a compensation package with partner Mitsubishi Motors which will see it buy out its stake in Fuso.
11. Looking forward, DaimlerChrysler's profits are expected to be slightly higher in 2005. However, it is expecting "significant improvements" in profitability in 2006 as a result of a major investment in the Mercedes product range.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about car companies and their financials. Let me read through the text carefully.

First, the main topic seems to be that DaimlerChrysler (Mercedes-Benz's parent) is struggling with profits after a big slump caused by Mercedes having poor performance in the luxury car market. Mercedes-Benz itself has faced some tough times too. They have lower sales and profits compared to 2003, which was a huge drop.

The text mentions that DaimlerChrysler's shares fell because of the financial issues with Mercedes-Benz, but they're back on their feet now. There are positive signs for DaimlerChrysler, especially after they managed to make some progress in 2005 and expect better things in 2006.

I should focus on the key points: the decline in profits for both companies, the reasons like high costs of new models and losses from the smart car range, DaimlerChrysler's efforts to recover, their performance compared to previous years, and the overall outlook.

Let me try to condense all that into a clear summary. I need to make sure I include the main events, especially about the sales decline and profits, and highlight DaimlerChrysler's recovery.
</think>

DaimlerChrysler's profits have experienced a significant drop after losing traction in the luxury car market, leading to lower sales and operating profits compared to 2003. Mercedes-Benz has also faced tough financials, with profits falling to just €20 million from an earlier record of €245 million. DaimlerChrysler's shares fell due to these issues but have since improved, taking a hit in costs associated with a defective joint venture and aiming for better performance next year. They expect mixed results in 2005 and expect significant improvements in 2006 after investing heavily in Mercedes' product range. Overall, DaimlerChrysler faces challenges but has strong signs of recovery.
tinyllama:1.1b: The luxury car maker DaimlerChrisler posted a slump in profitability during the fourth quarter due to challenging economic conditions and higher launch costs for new models, while their subsidiary Chrryser recorded a strong performance with increased sales and revenue. The company's overall net income rose by 400 million euros, boosted by a surge in unit sales, despite a full year operating loss of 506 million euros, which was attributed to lower profits from Mercedes-Benz. Despite the challenging economic environment, DaimlerChrisler posted worldwide vehicle sales growth of 8%, while overall revenues added 4% to 142 billion euros. The company's strategy worked well in spite of the challenges faced, and they are expecting "significant improvements" in profitability in 2006, as a result of major investments in their Mercedes product range.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The car giant Mercedes slumped into a $1bn (€1 billion) loss last year due to its high launch costs for new models and lower profits from its mini-car brand Smart, which was struggling with sales declines. The company blamed this decline on high launch costs and the loss of market share due to intense competition in the luxury car sector. Mercedes-Benz's profitability dropped to 20m euros ($1bn) for 2003, while its operating profits fell to just 20m euros.

The company's performance was significantly affected by its poor launch of new models in the United States. Sales of Mercedes-Benz brands fell 2% during the year as demand cooled. The carmaker blamed these sales losses on high launch costs for new models and lower profits from its Mercedes Smart mini-car range.

Mercedes' overall performance was positive, with worldwide vehicle sales rising by 8% to 4.7 million units in 2004. However, the company's profitability suffered due to a defects scandal at its joint venture, Fuso, which led to a loss of 455m euros. The carmaker's competitive pressure also contributed to this decline.

Despite these challenges, DaimlerChrysler maintained its reputation for stability and growth. The company agreed a $475m compensation package with Mitsubishi Motors, which will see it buy out its stake in Fuso as part of a major investment plan. Looking forward, DaimlerChrysler's profitability is expected to be slightly higher in 2005 and significantly improved in 2006 due to an investment in the Mercedes product range.
phi:2.7b: The slump in profitability at luxury car maker Mercedes has caused a big drop in profits for its parent company DaimlerChrysler. Mercedes-Benz's profits fell to 20m euros, while sales of Mercedes' brands decreased by 2% due to competition from BMW and financial losses from their Smart mini-car line. To improve profitability, Mercedes plans to increase productivity and retain its position as the world's most successful luxury brand. In contrast, Chrysler saw a 5% annual increase in unit sales and a 10% revenue growth in the US division, which turned a full year operating loss into a profit of 1.4bn euros. Overall, DaimlerChrysler had increased vehicle sales by 8% to 4.7 million in 20046, but suffered a 475m euro cost from a Fuso defects scandal. The company expects higher profits in 20057 and significant improvements in 20062 due to an investment in the Mercedes product range.
orca-mini:3b: Mercedes-Benz's profit slumped 46% to 1.6 billion euros in 2004 due to high launch costs and losses from its Mercedes Smart mini-car range, while parent company DaimlerChrysler saw worldwide vehicle sales rise 8% to 4.7 million and total revenues add 4% to 142 billion euros. Chrysler enjoyed a 5% annual increase in unit sales while revenues - calculated in US dollars - rose 10%. The US division, whose marques include Dodge and Jeep, transformed a full year operating loss of 506m euros in 2003 into a 1.4bn euros profit last year. DaimlerChrysler's strategy worked well despite intense competition, but it is expecting significant improvements in profitability in 2006 as a result of major investments in the Mercedes product range.
hermes3:3b: Merces drops profits at DaimlerChyral, Mercedes faces competition & price cuts, quarterly losses & high model costs blamed, hopes to revive by 2006.

The company blamed high launch costs for new models and losses from its Mercedes Smart mini-car range for the decline. However, parent DaimlerChrysler saw worldwide vehicle sales rise 8% to 4.7 million in 2004, with total revenues adding 4% to 142bn euros. The expectation is that profits will slightly increase in 2005 before improving significantly in 2006 due to a major investment in the Mercedes product range.
chatgpt-4o-latest: DaimlerChrysler's fourth-quarter operating profits dropped sharply to 785m euros from 2.4bn euros in 2003, mainly due to a slump at Mercedes-Benz, whose profits fell to just 20m euros. Mercedes struggled with high launch costs, losses from its Smart mini-car range, and competition from BMW, leading to a 46% decline in annual operating profits. The company aims to boost productivity and revive its fortunes by 2006. In contrast, Chrysler performed well, turning a 506m euro loss in 2003 into a 1.4bn euro profit, with a 5% rise in unit sales. DaimlerChrysler's overall vehicle sales grew 8% to 4.7 million, and total revenues increased 4% to 142bn euros. The company also took a 475m euro hit from a defects scandal at its Japanese subsidiary Fuso. Despite current struggles, DaimlerChrysler expects slightly higher profits in 2005 and significant improvements in 2006 due to major investments in Mercedes.
stablelm2:1.6b: DaimlerChrysler faced a drop in operating profits due to a slump in Mercedes' profits. The German-US carmaker saw its fourth quarter operating profits fall to €105 million ($1 billion) from €2.4 billion in the previous year. Despite this, the Chrysler group's returns met market expectations. Mercedes is hoping to increase productivity by €3 billion and improve its position as the world's most successful luxury brand. The carmaker blamed high launch costs for new models and losses from its Mercedes Smart mini-car range for the fall in profits.
granite3.1-dense:2b: DaimlerChrysler, a German-US carmaker, experienced a significant drop in profits due to Mercedes-Benz's struggles in the luxury car market. Mercedes' operating profits fell to 20m euros from 784m euros in 2003, largely attributed to high launch costs for new models and losses from the Smart mini-car range. This performance contrasts sharply with Chrysler's strong year, which saw a 5% increase in unit sales and a 10% rise in revenues (calculated in US dollars). Despite Mercedes' setbacks, DaimlerChrysler managed to maintain overall worldwide vehicle sales at 4.7 million units, resulting in an 8% increase in total revenues to 142bn euros for the year. The company attributes its success to Chrysler's robust performance and plans to invest more in the Mercedes product range, aiming for enhanced profitability in 2006. However, DaimlerChrysler shares dropped upon the release of these results due to ongoing concerns about Mercedes-Benz's struggles.
